Poverty has not dropped in India only the definition of poverty has changed. The previous definition allowed that if a head of a family made 100 rupees or roughly the equivalent of 23 cents a day they were not living in poverty or impoverished. Now it is 13 cents a day or some nonsense. Eventually, India will have to revise the definition. I think it will bottom out at 5 cents a day.

Steve, Thank you so much for your comment! I'm an ESL/EFL teacher originally from the former Soviet Union, now teaching English online from the US. This sounds like a great topic to be explored at the TESOL convention, I'd love to do more research for that... I have worked with the native speakers who had very limited command of any other foreign language, and thus their perception of learning a language was idealistic at best. The concept of repetition and other common drills for mastering a foreign language was virtually non-existent. As one American colleague told me at a TESOL convention a few years ago, "They repeat because that's how they learned anything in THEIR countries." Anyway, before I get on my soap box I'd like to thank you for your contribution and a very relevant comment.

Dr Ramchandra Guha, a historian made to order, is not known for intellectual honesty. Dr Ambedkar played a very prominent part in making the Constitution of India, but he was not its architect. It is not that Dr Guha does not know this, but he is economical with truth in appearing as politically correct. A noted political scientist ,K V Rao , very aptly observed that Dr Ambedkar could be described as the " mother of Indian Constitution" as he took the ideas of the Committees, generally headed by one of the three - Nehru, Patel and Azad, and incorporated the ideas as provisions of the Constitution. The Drafting Committee, headed by Ambedkar, was constituted on August 29, 1947; but the contours of the Constitution were decided by then. Besides, Dr Ambedkar was not chosen Chairman of the Drafting Committee because of his social background but because of his legal - constitutional expertise. Beverley Nicholas wrote in 1946 that Ambedkar was one of the six best brains in India.

Gandhiji was a catalyst for social change. He had criticized Hinduism's practice of untouchability of the Harijans-his term for Dalits- calling it inhumane. Ambedkar was the Chair of the Council charting the Indian Constitution. Many of the articles of the constitution were already proposed and passed by Indian National Congress in its plenary sessions. Universal suffrage, Secularism, removal of untouchbility were promised after Independence. After independence laws were passed to outlaw Hindu practice of untouchability.

Gandiji had always fought against British Policy of "divide and rule". British wanted to create a seperate constituancy for the dalits. He was in prison in Yeravada near Pune at the time. He had gone on aFast unto death against this proposal against this proposal mainly to avoid fragmentation of the populace.

I believe social change is an extremely slow process. We need laws that promote equality but also agents of change that ask for their rights. Even then prejudice born of hundreds even thousands of years is hard to eradicate. Though prejudice remains, today there are many States where Dalit Parties have won and are in control. Mainly this is a result of demography and universal franchise.

Dr. Ambedkar was a Legal Scholar who shaped the Indian Constitution and undoubtedly deserves credit, and codified the change that was prevalent in the Indian milieu at the time.

While India generally need to become more investor friendly (and not just foreign) the dark threats in the Western press about foreign capital fleeing because of every little change that makes things a little inconvenient is mostly self serving nonsense. Remember how holding the line on Enron was supposed to be terrible for future investments in India? There were lots of ridiculous articles, even after the company collapsed in the US.

In this case the finance minister is actually right that most companies are not investing in India because of tax advantages. And any that are that sensitive to small changes to cost of doing business will flee at the first chance for some other reason. Note the pretty large shift in very price sensitive call center jobs to Philippines and places in Africa, but not the software jobs a bit up the ladder.

Though there are failures in Indian armament industry, the writer is ALSO throwing the baby with bathwater. He has gone to far in castigating Indian armament industry. The Indian missile program has done well. There are also other - albeit spotty - successes such as the Dhruv helicopter program.

That is not to say that the industry is devoid of problems. There are many. The causes are also many. In addition to government/bureaucratic/political meddling, one major problem is hugely inordinate focus on IT and that too as a service industry only. Very little attention is paid to the manufacturing industry. When was the last time one bought a made in India machine, a hand tool, an appliance or whatever (other than clothing) in North America?

This reader is well aware of the shortage of competent engineers and scientists in India. Engineering colleges are mushrooming all over; but what is the quality of teachers and the subsequent output, students? Also, inordinate focus is also on mushrooming MBA programs - a no value added discipline that does NOTHING in developing quality manufactured goods. These so-called "MBA-Baboos" want to wear a suit and a tie and work for a investment bank (which also does NOT add wealth to a nation) in an ivory tower.

India has to change strategically as well as tactically to improve manufacturing. Government also has stop interfering. There is no other choice.

To continue..

This reader is a graduate of of one of the IITs - the very first one as a matter of fact. Many, many bright students from this IIT have opted over the years and still opt for the IT industry (here too NOT ONE of the major players - such as Tata, Infosys, etc., etc. - has created and supported a major IT product; they are all after easy money, essentially by working as bodyshops).

Just about anything - ANYTHING - in India is chaotic. Some say that India is still progressing with high GDP growth. However, many problems such as corruption is slowing down its growth and are forcing India to lose windows of opportunities.

It is not just a shame, to this reader it is a crime to see the way things happen in India. Only when Indians travel abroad with an open mind, they realize what India truly is and what it could have been - its glorious past notwithstanding.
live and let live.
